content.rendered: Surprised Ken that you left off Juanes (albeit another language: Spanish) version. Been a fan for a long time and he takes a tired and worn out song and makes it sound so fresh and new.
Great great story. Had heard bits and pieces about it but never from someone so intimately involved! Nice 👍✌️
Speak for yourself Erin. I enjoyed the Human Touch Tour. I had waited 5 years to see Bruce again.
Thank you so much for the warm note, Joe! I appreciate the empathy, and I hope you find the site to your liking.

My sympathies. Be kind to yourself. I just discovered your site/blog from this post.

My Dad died on July 4, 2020 and I found out early in the morning from my Brother. My Mom was in assisted living sleeping in the next bed over (she is blind). I listened to “my fathers house” in our backyard while waiting for my brother to come to the facility so that we could tell her (me on Facetime because of covid fears of flying at that point) that my Dad in the bed next to hers was now no longer. She was and remains the strongest person I know and handled it amazingly well. “The Wish” is my “go to” song when thinking about my Mom (very much alive at the age of 96). July 9 would have been their 60th anniversary so they almost got there. I had a similar relationship with my father as you described yours. He was a kind man and did lots for others but was very evangelical religious and me not so much and he could never get past that. Dad taught me a lot by how he handled situations and I like to think that he enjoyed life more than he showed. Sending good thoughts your way internet stranger!
Thanks for the reasoned criticism, Dave. You make great points.

As usual, your analysis is excellent. I truly appreciate what you’ve written and what Bruce is trying to do with this song. In this case, however, I think there is a wide gap between the idea/sentiment and the execution. In my opinion, the flaws of the song outweigh and overtake the message.

Musically, I hear Arthur’s Theme by Christopher Cross. There’s a comparison I never thought I’d make, but the opening of both songs are very, very similar. I try to ignore this but it’s too strong.

The lyrics are strong, as you describe. But the line itself: “house of a thousand guitars” – it lands with a thud. I don’t know what the problem is, exactly. It’s like it has too many syllables squeezed into too small a space, and the sounds are too dissimilar to work well together. To my ears, that line sounds forced and awkward every time he sings it. And again to my ears, it’s just not a meaningful or poetic line. It means nothing and is the worst line in the song.

And he sings it over and over again. I truly love Bruce’s music from the last 20 years, but when it’s not strong it often has the same flaw: an over reliance on one lyric. Songs like Surprise, Surprise or Working on a Dream, or Letter to You (but I agree with you about the acoustic version) and House of a Thousand Guitars – go back to the same repeated piece of melody and lyric over and over again and just beat you over the head. At least that’s what they do to me.

House of a Thousand Guitars has grown on me since I first heard it, but if I’m honest it makes me cringe a bit every time I hear it, and every time I hear Bruce sing that clunky lyric over and over and over again.

Thanks again for your analysis and the time and energy you’ve put into this site.
Danke!
War sehr ergriffen von Deinem Beitrag und kenne ähnliche Situationen. Behalte die guten Gedanken in Dir. Mein Beileid und die besten wünsche aus Eutin, Germany
What a beautiful, beautiful narrative this morning. May your father Rest In Peace, and may you be comforted by warm memories. Your work is such a gift to us, thank you and bless you and your family.

So sorry for your loss, but also happy for your gain; you found things from and with your father that you might never have found without the journey you two took, and the one you each take now moving forward. Thanks for writing such a beautiful, moving, & powerful post.
I hear almost every father-son story in here. It is beautiful. And my deepest condolences for your own loss.

May your dads memory be a blessing now and always. You shared a wonderful moment if your life. Thank you for opening your heart to us. Listening to Bruce’s words And maturing alongside has lent a side of me that seems to always find comfort listening over And over again
I’m very sorry for your loos, may he rest in peace
My condolences Ken but my thanks also for another, possibly your best, post. You have insights and a way with words to deliver them. I’m sure your dad will always have been very proud of you.
Condolences, Ken. What a lovely and meaningful rememberance to share.

Ken, Thank you for sharing your father’s spirit–and now much of yours–with us. I think it is great you will carry on the legacy of your father’s positive influences. (“I unchained a door in my heart, welcomed all the wonderful traits and idiosyncrasies that made him my dad, and invited them to find a nook and make themselves comfortable.”) The included photo of your father was also appreciated. May your father rest in peace.
My condolences to you and your family on the loss of your father. Your essay on the song was beautiful as well.
I’ve been reading these posts for over a year and I’ve anxiously waited for this song to be covered. My condolences go out to you and your family during this rough time. Take care Ken.
Oh man. That was beautiful. Holding space for you.
So sorry to hear about your dad Ken. Thank you for sharing these moving reflections.
Beautifully written. I am so sorry. I am tears, I lost my Dad last year, almost the same age, and your story hit very close to home. Please know uour in my thoughts.

Very sorry for your loss. My Dad passed at 53. I was 19. I am nearly 72 and think about him pretty much every day, as well as all the lost opportunities to spend time together. My son & I will be seeing Bruce in NYC in a few weeks. We are fortunate to have had a good relationship. Best wishes to you and family.

Ken
I have always found your posts engaging. On this occasion you’ve moved me to tears. Like Bruce, you’ve told your story in a way that is specifically about and your father you is but totally relatable to all of us. I salute your bravery in sharing. Thank you so much
Steve

I am so deeply sorry for the loss of your Father Ken. You and your family are in my thoughts and prayers. You have brought so much joy to the Bruce community and we are here for you because WTCOOO. May your Dad rest easy Ken ❤️🙏
My condolences to you and your family, Ken. Thanks for sharing your thoughts in this column, I know it’s not easy. Your Dad sounds like a wonderful man. Take care.
So sorry for your loss, Ken. Thank you for sharing your memories with us….this was great and very moving. Take care. Much love to you and your family.
So sorry for your loss — this is so beautifully written, as is all your work.
Such a gorgeous tribute to your Dad. So sorry for your loss… may the memories carry your love until you meet again…

You have described a very similar relationship I had with my father Ken so eloquently.
Be with your family & my condolences to you all my friend
Simon.
Loved the song interpretation and loved the feelings conveyed in your post! I’m sorry for your loss, cherish the memories.
That’s a beautiful post Ken, please accept my condolences for you and your family.
I’m very sorry for your loss. Thank you for sharing such a personal and thoughtful post.
You have my condolences on the loss of your father. Hold close your memories of him and visit them often. That way he is never truly gone from your life.

Ken, Please accept my deepest condolences on the loss of your father. Your post was a beautiful tribute to your complex relationship. I will be thinking of you and your family over the next week. May your father Rest In Peace.

Losing a parent is so hard. When I heard the part of Bruce’s dad in the Broadway show I related so well to that. My dad could sell hot chocolate on a 10@ degree day in Phoenix….. I find myself doing the same things like him. Just like Bruce said he did…..
Prayers for you 🙏🙏🙏🙏

Beautifully written post, thank you so much for sharing your story and insightful interpretation of My Father’s House. I agree with your thoughts 100%. My condolences to you and your family on your loss.
Sorry for your loss Ken. Loved the post and it nurtured a good many buried memories of my own dad who has been gone for 20 years. I appreciate you and wish you peace though your grieving.
You and me both, Trudie.

That was beautiful! I first heard The River shortly after my youngest daughter was born, and I was hormonal as hell. No walks down the aisle, no wedding day smile, no flowers, no wedding dress broke my heart, and I swore my daughters would have the weddings they wanted no matter the circumstances. They are grown up with families of their own now, and yes, they both had beautiful weddings. And the song still makes me cry…

Very funny and love the “in depth analysis” of his ANSWERING MACHINE MESSAGE. He should have just gone with “belive it or not Bruce isn’t at home, just leave at…well you get the idea. Contrast this with Paul Westerberg’s I hate your answering machine…Could only imagine what the Replacements had on their machines. Thanks for the laugh Ken.
This should’ve been the B-side to Hungry Heart
This is great!!! I’m going to see if I can put it on my phone.
The Revivalists captured the sound and spirit of Born to Run! Love the sax solo!
Well worth sharing, thank you
Very impressive!
AWESOME

A great and important “Cover Me” of the fantastic “Let It Be Me”! There is much I did not know (original English record/Jill Corey; “Becaud” singing the original French take–although the video appears to be from the mid-60s; etc.)

Always felt that Bruce’s “intimate arrangement” of “Let It Be Me” and other “Tunnel of Love” ’88 tour inclusions (i.e. “Lonely Teardrops”, 5.22; “Crying”, 5.16; “Cautious Man, 5.10; “Crying In The Rain, 5.6) were indeed the result of “Bruce and Patti growing more intimate” (KR). The emotional strain, pathos and excitement of “sweet love” surely plays out in the performances of these songs and others.

Yeah, each time we meet ‘love’
I feel (find) so complete love
Without your sweet love
What good would I be?–Chapel Hill, 3.4.88

Wow! And the romanticism brought by the T.O.L. Horns during the Chapel Hill soundcheck is truly devastating. Thanks for the research, writing and memories.

Much enjoyed the studio track (cleanly produced) and live take of “Dirty Rotten Shame”. Great to hear Garry sing on both. Got to LOVE Bruce and Garry sharing a mic during the live version. Great to see Garry playing the six-string rhythm and the classic Vox amp in the background.
Thanks, Ken. What a take by Elvis, Scotty, and Bill!
Wonder if Bruce and Patti got to meet Lauren Bacall. She was also part of the 97 Kennedy Center honors with Bob Dylan. In fact Ms. Bacall and Mr. Dylan sat next to each other.

What a “Cover Me” (Bruce sings “The Times They Are A-Changin'” at Kennedy Center Honors)! If I know anything about KR, this was chosen as a sign of these times. Much appreciate your insight. And, I believe, Bruce sang all the lyrics.

Nope that was an accident. The original video was taken down, and I noticed the broken link a couple weeks ago and grabbed another one that looked like it was the right one (without bothering to listen first). That’ll show me. Fixed now, thanks for the catch!

Ken, Love this Cover Me of “Mystery Train” and its deep history including Junior Parker’s original and the “great, great Sam Phillips” production. May I ask, was it intentional not to include the Elvis’ 1955 (#77, RS Greatest) take, but instead, show the photo collage of “Elvis 56” accompanied by atmospheric music?

Wow, no kidding! “(H)e absolutely owned “Radio Nowhere,” elevating it to a new level with his fierce playing.” (KR) Jay and Bruce cannot hide their joy and enthusiasm during the song’s conclusion as shown in the above 2009 video. Nils and father Max also join in to display their appreciation for Jay’s work. Fun ROTD!
Solaris…
Enjoy your well deserved vacation!

+1 enjoy! When going deeper into the Streets of Philly song, The Advocate interview from 1996 will be always an interesting companion time piece, see here for a complete transcription https://www.greasylake.org/v6/display_article.php?essential=yes&Id=18&headline=Bruce+Springsteen%3A+The+Advocate+Interview&publication=The+Advocate&concert_date=&release_title=
Enjoy your hiatus, I’m looking forward to delving into the album index.
Enjoy your vacation and thank you for all your engaging and well written posts. Heading to your SOB 2021 Backstreers post now!

Ken, Much enjoyed your detailed review of S.O.B. II. As an obvious die-hard, your courage of constructive criticism was appreciated (i.e. “The shift in voice and style often took me out of the moment, where the original held my rapt and full attention throughout”). Still, you found the emotional heart of Bruce’s performance (“As a work of art, the revival doesn’t hold a candle to the original; as a rite of communion, it completely transcends it”). WOW!
Your writing, photos and videos provided great imagery for those of us not there. “As Bruce strummed those notes, all color returned to the world.” Indeed.

Thank you so much. Enjoy your deserved vacation. We will miss you until then.
Enjoy and thank you for all you do
You do a fantastic job Ken! I love what you do. Enjoy your time off, come back refreshed!
Well deserved, Ken. Thank you for brightening and Brucifying every day.
Enjoy your vacation, Ken! It is richly deserved!
I’m loving this one, it actually reminds me very much of the Faces. Thank you for putting a spotlight on these old obscure originals.
Yep sarcasm mode definitely enabled

“It’s a complete coincidence that at the very moment Bruce exploded into mainstream stardom with Born to Run in the autumn of 1975, Campbell’s song was riding the top of the charts.” (Am I right in assuming sarcasm was intended?) Appreciate your insight into this. Never made the connection until now.

“There’ll be a load of compromising,
On the road to my horizon,
But I’m gonna be where the lights are shining on me…”

A great “Cover”!
The dice will always rock n roll on bosssssss
Propriety?
Great job as always. Given all that, why did he have the dedication to the album be “Thanks Juli”?

wow, I’d never even hear OF them doing this! Great recording, too!

GP & The Rumour did “Chain of Fools” on their ‘Live at Marble Arch’ album, which was, I think, a promotional album made to look like a bootleg (much like the Southside ‘Jukes At The Bottom Line’)
Haha yes! Sesame Street song! I hear that niw too! Too funny. Very catchy riff for sure.

Great catch! Although i don’t think it could have been an influence on Bruce’s song, as we have a recording of him playing it in September 1971 as well. Maybe the Bradys were influenced by Sesame Street too! 🙂

Hi Ken

Listen to Sunshine Day by the Brady Bunch on You Tube. Also released in 1972. A very catchy tune indeed. Sounds like it was an ear worm for Bruce too. Check it out!

Great article.

SHC ’11

I was there at Red Rocks for this song. It rained before the concert (despite a beautiful afternoon sound check) and he opened with “Who’ll Stop the Rain” and then came out for the second set with “Sea Cruise” – both were absolutely magical and spot on! Still one of my favorite Bruce and E Street Band moments.
I was in Orlando 😎
Wow! One of the best covers (of any song) you’ve featured.
It’s wonderful! Thanks for sharing it, and good luck in the contest!
Thank you Ken! Glad you like it.

Love Patti’s observation of the King’s influence for the Viva Las Vegas doc, “Elvis for me is a symbol of tremendous promise and a kind of American hopefulness.” Wow! (Bruce’s harmonica embellishments are so grounded and inspired and, as mentioned, “Looking For Elvis” would have fit ideally with the Magic Tour.) A great MATR.
“I’m looking for Elvis down a Memphis road”, indeed!

“Who put the ram in the rama lama ding dong?”
“I’m goin’ down, down, down–hey-a-bop-a-de down, down.” (This was fun!)
Learned something–“vocalise”. Yes, Bruce and E Street do indeed “shine throughout” and clearly are having a “blast”.
Ken, thanks for putting in the work.
Damn. Life goes by way too fast and it is a sobering thought when you realize there less days ahead of you than behind

Fantastic work Ken. I think it serves to strengthen my argument that Badlands also deals with depression. ‘Caught in a crossfire that I don’t understand’ – what better description of confusing intrusive thoughts?

And ‘It ain’t no sun to be glad you’re alive’ implies that the narrator finds this experience elusive.

He wants to be lifted out of his depression ‘raise me above these Badlands’

Forgive me for banging on but I really think your elegant and perceptive analysis of SITN opens the door for my take on Badlands.

Anyway- thank you once again got bringing ‘Something’ to life for me

Steve
Great insight to a great song on what I consider Bruce’s best album.👍

Nice review! One of my favorite songs too. Years ago, I wrote a zine called Revolution of the Heart where I reviewed some of my favorite songs and “This Time Baby’s Gone for Good” was among them. The zine is posted on my site.
